Introductory Pharmacology and Toxicology","description":"

This course will cover the basic principles of Pharmacology with an emphasis on drug action from the molecular and cellular levels to tissue, organ and whole organism levels. The course will provide an understanding of the principles of drug action (Pharmacodynamics) in terms of drug chemistry, drug-receptor interaction, receptor theory and dose-response relationships. An introduction to receptor-mediated signal transduction, membrane receptors and autonomic pharmacology will be covered. The handling of drugs by the body through the processes of absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion (Pharmacokinetics) will be covered in some detail along with drug analysis and the adverse effects of drugs. The laboratory classes will involve students performing real and computer-simulated pharmacological experiments.

This assessment will be in the format of MCQ and short answer questions.  Questions will be based on the material covered in the lectures, practical classes and tutorials.

This assessment will be in the format of MCQ and short answer questions.  Questions will be based on the material covered in the lectures, practical classes and tutorials. Results will be posted on Moodle when graded.  There will also be a feedback session during a tutorial class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d61b239c1b422410d5fb0fabdc4bcb4f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"da1b239c1b422410d5fb0fabdc4bcb4e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"de1b239c1b422410d5fb0fabdc4bcb4f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"de1b239c1b422410d5fb0fabdc4bcb50","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"561b239c1b422410d5fb0fabdc4bcba6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Written Commentary Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

  • Students will complete this assessment task in multiple stages. Students will first submit notes they have taken from their own research, and then prepare and submit a commentary regarding an allocated article from the scientific literature. Students will peer review and provide feedback on the commentaries submitted by two other students. Upon receiving feedback on their own commentary, students will revise their commentary and respond to the feedback they received. 

  • A marking rubric will be used to evaluate each student’s revised commentary, response to feedback, and the quality of feedback they provided when reviewing other peers’ commentaries. Students will receive feedback in the form of comments inserted into the submitted PDF documents via GradeMark. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d61b239c1b422410d5fb0fabdc4bcb4f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d61b239c1b422410d5fb0fabdc4bcb50","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"961b239c1b422410d5fb0fabdc4bcbb8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Continuous Assessment Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

  • Lab quizzes (2 x 2.5%) will take place during practical classes, and will assess students’ understanding of the concepts addressed in the practical classes, as well as their preparation for the classes. Lab quizzes will be marked right after the quiz and students will receive feedback during the class. 

  • The online quizzes (2 x 2.5%) takes place early in the term and is in the form of MCQs. It is designed to help students revise the teaching content, and become familiar with the MCQ format. Students will receive their assessment results and feedback immediately following completion of the quiz.

This course will explore the process of drug development, from target identification to final drug registration. It will present drug development as a process involving target selection, hit discovery using computer-based methods and combinatorial chemistry/high-throughput screening. Lead identification and optimisation via the use of structure activity series and computational methods will be covered. Safety evaluation, bioavailability, clinical trials, and the essentials of intellectual property, regulatory affairs and commercialisation will also be discussed. Along the way, you will learn about screening assays, computer-aided drug design, and toxicology as applied to the development of new medicines.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3c8bceafdbb59850eb6b147a3a961919","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Progress Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

This assessment will be in the format of short and long answer questions, and will last for 45 minutes.  Questions will test student’s knowledge of the process of drug design and development, and their ability to apply the knowledge acquired from lectures, tutorials and practical classes. Results will be posted on Moodle when graded.  There will also be a feedback session during a practical class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a08bceafdbb59850eb6b147a3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a48bceafdbb59850eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"908b8eafdbb59850eb6b147a3a9619d1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Manuscript","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will prepare a research manuscript using the data collected across the three Hit optimisation practicals plus the computational drug design practical. Feedback will be provided via a marking rubric used to evaluate each manuscript, along with additional comments inserted into the submitted PDF document via turnitin feedback studio.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a48bceafdbb59850eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f08bceafdbb59850eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"908b8eafdbb59850eb6b147a3a9619e2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Therapeutic Product Development History","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Stages of Drug Design and Development Process 

Part 1: Therapeutic product development history timelines.

Each team will produce a timeline of the drug design and development process of their assigned drug, highlighting the major milestone and challenges faced in the journey that the drug took from bench to bedside. The timeline should cover the 4 major stages of the drug design and development process. The teams can use any medium to produce their timeline (e.g. a video, an animation, infographic) with the overall aim to educate a peer audience about the major milestones along the path the drug took from bench to bedside. Feedback will be provided via a grading rubric and written feedback.

Part 2: Peer Feedback

Each student will provide feedback on the effectiveness of the timeline of the drug design and development in educating them about the major milestones and challenges faced. Each student will review 2 timelines and will be assessed on their effective use of the RISE model of peer feedback. The groups will then write a 250-word summary of what they would do to improve their timeline based on the feedback received. Feedback will be provided via a grading rubric and written feedback in turnitin feedback studio.

Part 3: Teamwork in the stages of the drug discovery and development process

Each student team will produce an item to educate a peer audience (a video, an animation, infographic) that explores teamwork in the pharmaceutical industry. This could include the use of cross-functional teams, the roles within teams at each stage of the process and how they work together in or across each stage of the drug design and development process. Feedback will be provided via a grading rubric and written feedback. Team members will also provide peer assessment of each members individual contribution to the team across the ‘Stages of drug design and development process’ assignment.

You will learn the molecular basis of drug action and explore how cutting-edge biotechnology and biomedical research advances pharmacological knowledge. Detailed coverage includes: genetic variability in drug action, protein structure-activity relationships, receptor-ligand interactions, signal transduction, biochemical and molecular aspects of drug targets and their signalling mechanisms.  The course has a strong focus on developing research and analytical skills.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d6d32a9ddbcad090eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d6d32a9ddbcad090eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ded32a9ddbcad090eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ded32a9ddbcad090eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3ed32a9ddbcad090eb6b147a3a96195d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Laboratory Notebook","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will record the details of each experiment performed during the practical classes, collect and analyse data, and draw conclusions from the data generated. Students will be receiving formative feedback during practical classes and 3-4 times during the term their laboratory notebook will be graded. After each submission they will receive summative feedback. A marking rubric will be used to evaluate the laboratory notebooks and provide feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d6d32a9ddbcad090eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d6d32a9ddbcad090eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ded32a9ddbcad090eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ded32a9ddbcad090eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a6d32a9ddbcad090eb6b147a3a96194d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Collaborative Learning Activities","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Part 1: Molecular Technique Quizzes: Students will take online quizzes covering the application of molecular techniques to pharmacological studies. (5 quizzes, 5%). 

\n

Part 2: Journal Club. 'Journal cub' will be scheduled every second week (please note this may be subject to change due to public holidays). Students will answer questions that guide them through the process of analysing and drawing conclusions from data presented in a research article which has used the molecular techniques taught in the collaborative learning session the week before. Students submit answers prior to each 'journal club'. At the end of semester students reflect on their critical analysis learning trajectory and nominate their “best” attempt at answering the questions for marking. (10%)

\n

Clinical Pharmacology for Health and Exercise Science introduces students to the basic principles of pharmacology with an emphasis on the interaction of drugs and exercise. The course will provide students with an understanding of the principles of drug action (pharmacodynamics) in terms of drug chemistry, drug-receptor interaction, receptor signalling and dose-response relationships and how the body handles drugs. Students will gain an appreciation of the mechanisms by which drugs act utilizing clinical examples and the impact of treatment on acute and chronic responses to exercise in major health conditions.

The format for the final examination will be 30 multiple choice questions and 6 x 10 min written questions (from 8 questions).

The final examination will be based on the material covered in the lectures; however, material covered in the tutorials and practical classes can also be examinable. Material covered from weeks 6-10 will be examined.    

The final examination will address graduate attributes A, B and F.

Assessment Description

Students will work in teams to research a given topic for presentation as a scientific poster. Posters will be displayed and presented during a designated practical class time slot. Students will be expected to answer questions relating to their group’s given topic both individually and as a group. Poster presentations will be graded on scientific content, visual communication and verbal presentation by academic/research reviewers or staff.

Feedback Process

A marking rubric will be used to evaluate this assignment, along with additional verbal feedback given to the students by the reviewers.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1bce5973db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"27ce9973db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96191b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"63ce9973db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96191e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"abce9973db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dbce5973db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e7ce9973db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961918","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4fce5973db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Assessment Description

A laboratory report will be written individually using combined class data generated and analysed (from a data analysis practical class) from a selected class. 

This assessment task will address graduate attributes A, B, C, D, E & F.

Feedback Process

A marking rubric will be used to evaluate this laboratory report, along with additional comments inserted into the submitted PDF document via turnitin. Students will then need to address the comments and make appropriate changes to the orginal submited laboratory report and submit a letter stating the changes made. A marking rubric will be used to evaluate the re-submited manuscript.

The progress examination will give you feedback on how you are succeeding in the course. The format is 30 multiple choice questions and 6 x 10 min written questions (from 8 questions).

The progress examination will be based on the material covered in the lectures; however, material covered in the tutorials and practical classes can also be examinable. Material covered from weeks 1-4 will be examined.    

The progress examinations will address graduate attributes A, B and F and give you feedback on how you are succeeding in the course.

The course will build on the information you have gained in Pharmacology (PHAR2011) and Physiology (2101 & 2201) as well as Biochemistry (BIOC2101/2181)), Molecular Biology (2201/2291), Chemistry (2021/2041) or Neuroscience Fundamentals (NEUR2201). This course will cover the basic principles of neuropharmacology with an emphasis on drug action on the central and peripheral nervous systems. The course will focus on how the major groups of neurotransmitters, including monoamines, amino acids and neuropeptides, influence the operation of the nervous system. Drugs targeting these transmitter systems will be examined. Issues surrounding drug entry into the central nervous system will be addressed. Clinical applications of neuropharmacology, the link between neuropharmacology and behaviour, and current research investigating the development of drugs for neuronal targets will be addressed. Practical classes will complement the lecture material.

Results will be posted on Moodle when graded. Overall class feedback on the test will be provided on Moodle and presented in a tutorial.

This assessment will be in the format of MCQ and short answer questions. There will be five online practical quizzes over the course of the term, each worth 2.5%. Students will receive individual written feedback on quizzes and results will be posted on Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"128bceafdbb59850eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1e8bceafdbb59850eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5e8bceafdbb59850eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"de8bceafdbb59850eb6b147a3a9619ea","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"868bceafdbb59850eb6b147a3a9619d8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"‘Controversial Research Topic in Neuropharmacology’","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will work in teams of 3-4 to research a “Controversial Research Topic in Neuropharmacology”. Each group member will participate in the development of an argument for or against a given topic, and present it to the class during the designated practical time slot (12.5%). Each group will be required to keep a log of the contributions made by each group member. Following the debate, individual group members will also submit a synopsis of their own group’s debate and research into the topic. The group oral presentation (research debate) is worth 12.5%, the group work log is worth 2.5%, and the individual written synopsis is worth 5%. Separate marking rubrics will be used to evaluate the group oral presentation, groupwork log and individual synopsis. Written feedback sheets will be returned to the group for the presentation, online written feedback will be provided on the groupwork logs and online written feedback will be provided for the synopsis. All results will be posted on Moodle.

contentlets.description: The course will build on the information you have gained in Pharmacology (PHAR2011) and Physiology (2101 & 2201) as well as Biochemistry (BIOC2101/2181)), Molecular Biology (2201/2291), Chemistry (2021/2041) or Neuroscience Fundamentals (NEUR2201). This course will cover the basic principles of neuropharmacology with an emphasis on drug action on the central and peripheral nervous systems. The course will focus on how the major groups of neurotransmitters, including monoamines, amino acids and neuropeptides, influence the operation of the nervous system. Drugs targeting these transmitter systems will be examined. Issues surrounding drug entry into the central nervous system will be addressed. Clinical applications of neuropharmacology, the link between neuropharmacology and behaviour, and current research investigating the development of drugs for neuronal targets will be addressed. Practical classes will complement the lecture material.
contentlets.title: Neuropharmacology

This course deals with the pharmacology of different drug classes, with an emphasis on the mode of drug action. Effects of drugs on the major organ systems will be covered, focusing on the cardiovascular, renal and endocrine systems, as well as chemotherapy. Students will be introduced to emerging therapeutic strategies based on advances in understanding cellular physiology and drug action. The practicals will cover basic pharmacological methods from both clinical and experimental standpoints.

The aim of the course is to provide vision science and clinical optometry students with a strong knowledge base in pharmacology and therapeutics that will benefit them in their future career. This will be achieved by providing the essential knowledge of the basic principles of pharmacology with an emphasis on drug action from the molecular and cellular levels to tissue, organ and whole organism levels. The course will provide an understanding of the principles of drug action (pharmacodynamics) in terms of, drug-receptor interaction, receptor theory and dose-response relationships. An introduction to receptor-mediated signal transduction, membrane receptors and autonomic pharmacology will be covered. The handling of drugs by the body through the processes of absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion (pharmacokinetics) will be covered in some detail along with drug analysis and the adverse effects of drugs. In addition, the pharmacology of different drug classes that target the major organ systems will be explored.

The course will focus on an introduction to the global therapeutics industry (pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, medical devices and diagnostics); the role of therapeutics in improving health outcomes; the history of the therapeutics industry; how companies are created and structured; current and future strategies for development of therapeutic technologies; the role of global trade agreements, regulatory harmonisation and the evolution of new models for funding innovation in future therapeutics development.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"da8796eddb969c10eb6b147a3a9619a4","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

The Reflective Journal is a core component of the Pharmaceutical Medicine Unit’s commitment to the development of students personal and professional skills and will involve a reflective online learning process. 

By the end of the program of study students will have evidence of their learning and will be able to demonstrate competencies required for future career advancement.

Active career planning is a central feature of this exercise. Students will be encouraged to reflect on the connections between their past, present and desired future skills, their current and future desired knowledge, their industry context, and the competencies and strategies required to achieve career success. Employment in the Australian pharmaceutical industry is very competitive and students will need to show prospective employers how they can meet their requirements and what competencies they will bring to the role.  

The Reflective Journal will be submitted and assessed within each course you study.  At the end of the course, please download a pdf or word version of their best 5 reflections and submit them through Turnitin.

This assessment task is designed to demonstrate an ability to integrate students' course learning with their work environment, knowledge of the pharmaceutical industry and self-development.  Self-reflection is a powerful learning tool and students are encouraged to use it throughout their career to discern their own performance and where they would like to make improvements.  It will also prepare them for job interviews, performance reviews and promotions.


Reflections will be submitted through Turnitin and individual feedback is given to students.  A marking rubric is provided to students for this assessment task.

Critique the financial drivers of current and future models of therapeutics development.

 

Assignments will be submitted through Turnitin and individual feedback will be given to students.  A marking rubric will be provided to students for this assessment task.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d28796eddb969c10eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9a87d6eddb969c10eb6b147a3a961963","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Discussion Forums","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Contributions to the section-specific discussion forums are required in this course. Students are expected to contribute at least one post to each Discussion Forum during the semester. Posts should be no more than 200 words excluding supportive references. Students should submit their top three plus a 200-word paragraph outlining why they have chosen those particular three posts and why they consider them to be their best contributions to the discussions. Individual feedback will be provided via GradeMark.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d28796eddb969c10eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d28796eddb969c10eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d68796eddb969c10eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"da8796eddb969c10eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ae87d6eddb969c10eb6b147a3a96196c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Therapeutic Product Development","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment task involves exploring the development of a therapeutic product and its contribution to health outcomes as part of a group.  The assessment task will be a wiki. 

Groups will choose one therapeutic product and indication from the list provided.  Students will be expected to review the contribution of their group members as well as peer review the final projects of other groups in the class.

This assessment task will develop students' skills in working cooperatively with colleagues located at a distance, similar to project teams they will be involved in when working in the therapeutics industry.  It will also help in the development of critical thinking skills by assessing their colleagues’ work and contributions to the team.  An ability to critically assess the work of others is vital in the industry setting, particularly as staff progress through their career to more senior managerial roles where they will supervise other staff.    


Students are expected to review the contribution of their group members as well as peer review the final projects of other groups in the class.  Marking rubrics are provided to students.

Regulatory Affairs is responsible for ensuring the company remains compliant with all legislation and regulations pertaining to the function of the company in a particular jurisdiction.  This course will provide an introduction to the regulation of therapeutic products, with particular reference to the Australian context.  It will introduce students to the Australian legal system within which the regulation of therapeutic products occurs.

Contributions to the section-specific discussion forums are required in this course. Students are expected to contribute at least one post to each Discussion Forum during the term. Posts should be no more than 200 words excluding supportive references. Students should submit their top three plus a 200-word paragraph outlining why they have chosen those particular three posts and why they consider them to be their best contributions to the discussions. Individual feedback will be provided via Grade and Mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8760ba00dbf75050358b403c3a96194d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0b60ba00dbf75050358b403c3a96194f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

This assessment task is designed to demonstrate an ability of students to integrate their course learning with their work environment, knowledge of the pharmaceutical industry and self-development.  Self-reflection is a powerful learning tool and can be applied throughout the student’s future career to discern their performance and where they should focus efforts to make improvements. Developing this skill and keeping a record of achievements and areas for improvement will prepare students for job interviews, performance reviews and promotions.


Students will be encouraged to reflect on the connections between their past, present and desired future skills, their current and future desired knowledge, their industry context, and the competencies and strategies required to achieve their career success. Employment in the pharmaceutical industry is very competitive and students will need to show prospective employers how they can meet their requirements and what competencies they will bring to their role.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8f60ba00dbf75050358b403c3a96194c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0b60ba00dbf75050358b403c3a961954","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will be presented with a data package to evaluate and use to construct an application to the TGA for either a new medicine or a change to an existing medicine.  The objectives of this task are to develop core skills needed by a regulatory affairs professional.  These skills include being able to:

1. Identify the regulatory process and evaluation cost that is appropriate to implement a change to an existing registered medicine.

2. Identify the supporting pharmaceutical chemistry data that is required to support the proposed change.

3. Communicate the proposed change in a letter of application to the TGA.

 

This assessment task is designed to give students the experience of real-life work as a regulatory affairs professional in order for them to understand this role in the industry.

It will help students to develop their written communication skills, literature research skills and critical thinking skills. The written documents generated are valid documents that students would be expected to produce in this industry.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8760ba00dbf75050358b403c3a96194e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9760ba00dbf75050358b403c3a961959","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Group project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will be assigned to groups and each group will be asked to address one or two questions regarding the Law paper for this course.  Students will work collaboratively on their response to their questions and post their responses in a Discussion Forum on the course site. Students will be expected to review the responses from the other groups and comment on at least two other group’s posts in the Discussion Forum. This will form part of the assessment mark. Written assessment will be provided.

This assessment task is designed to help students navigate the legal system in Australia and the laws that underpin the regulation of therapeutic products in Australia.  It is vital that students comprehend the legal requirements of the industry in which they intend to work. This task will also help students develop vital groupwork skills that are needed to work effectively in industry.

Student receive individual marks based on their individual engagement in the discussion forum and quality of their submission within the project.

Pharmaceutics deals with the science of making a chemical or biological entity suitable for delivery to humans as a therapeutic product.  It therefore covers formulation and manufacture of these products. This course will give students the skills to understand how different types of medicines are formulated and the effect of different formulations on the properties of the medicine and the manufacturing processes for the medicine. It will cover advanced formulations such as extended and modified release tablets, patches, injectables, biologicals (such as cell and tissue therapies) and delivery devices, as well as diagnostics.  Stability, bioavailability, bioequivalence and sterility requirements for medicines will be covered as will repurposing of medicines for new uses and development of new formulations.

Students will be provided with a scenario for a particular formulation for an active ingredient and asked to present an argument for the development of that formulation to the class. The assessment task will be presented as a wiki. Students will be expected to review the contribution of their group members as well as peer review the final projects of other groups in the class. This assessment task will develop students' skills in working cooperatively with colleagues located at a distance, similar to project teams they will be involved in when working in the therapeutics industry.  It will also help in the development of critical thinking skills by assessing their colleagues’ work and contributions to the team.  An ability to critically assess the work of others is vital in the industry setting, particularly as staff progress through their career to more senior managerial roles where they will supervise other staff.  Thirty marks will be group marks, while five marks will individual marks.

contentlets.keywords: pharmacology,pharmaceutical medicine,pharmaceutical,pharmaceutics,medicine manufacturing,medicine formulation,bioavailability,therapeutics,drug development,drug repurposing,gmp,good manufacturing practice,pharmaceutical manufacturing
contentlets.description: Pharmaceutics deals with the science of making a chemical or biological entity suitable for delivery to humans as a therapeutic product.  It therefore covers formulation and manufacture of these products. This course will give students the skills to understand how different types of medicines are formulated and the effect of different formulations on the properties of the medicine and the manufacturing processes for the medicine. It will cover advanced formulations such as extended and modified release tablets, patches, injectables, biologicals (such as cell and tissue therapies) and delivery devices, as well as diagnostics.  Stability, bioavailability, bioequivalence and sterility requirements for medicines will be covered as will repurposing of medicines for new uses and development of new formulations.
contentlets.title: Pharmaceutics

The course is designed to provide students with the skills in choosing and applying strategies for an application for a Therapeutic product to be registered and approved for marketing within Australia. Students will also examine approaches taken in the European Union and the USA and will be introduced to some regional jurisdictions such as Japan, China and south-east Asian countries.  The course also covers the regulation of genetically-modified organisms (GMOs) in Australia and elsewhere.  Students will learn about the emerging area of regulatory intelligence.  Finally they will investigate the role of regulatory strategy in supporting the commercial needs of the company.

Contributions to the section-specific discussion forums are required in this course. Students are expected to contribute at least one post to each Discussion Forum during the semester. Posts should be no more than 200 words excluding supportive references. Students should submit their top three plus a 200-word paragraph outlining why they have chosen those particular three posts and why they consider them to be their best contributions to the discussions. Individual feedback will be provided via GradeMark.

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4a1d56e5dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961968","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"521d56e5dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"521d56e5dbd69c10eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5a1d56e5dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"161d96e5dbd69c10eb6b147a3a96199d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

This assessment task is designed to demonstrate an ability of students to integrate their course learning with their work environment, knowledge of the pharmaceutical industry and self-development.  Self-reflection is a powerful learning tool and can be applied throughout the student’s future career to discern their performance and where they should focus efforts to make improvements. Developing this skill and keeping a record of achievements and areas for improvement will prepare students for job interviews, performance reviews and promotions.

\n


Students will be encouraged to reflect on the connections between their past, present and desired future skills, their current and future desired knowledge, their industry context, and the competencies and strategies required to achieve their career success. Employment in the pharmaceutical industry is very competitive and students will need to show prospective employers how they can meet their requirements and what competencies they will bring to their role.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"421d56e5dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961968","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5e1d96e5dbd69c10eb6b147a3a96199a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Groupwork Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be placed in groups, assigned a therapeutic product class and asked to review the regulatory environment in Australia versus another jurisdiction for that product class.  They will need to provide a comparison of the similarities and differences between the two systems and make recommendations for any appropriate improvements to both systems.  They will need to justify their evaluation of these systems and their recommendations. The assessment task will be presented as a wiki. Students will be expected to review the contribution of their group members as well as peer review the final projects of other groups in the class. This assessment task will develop students' skills in working cooperatively with colleagues located at a distance, similar to project teams they will be involved in when working in the therapeutics industry.  It will also help in the development of critical thinking skills by assessing their colleagues’ work and contributions to the team.  An ability to critically assess the work of others is vital in the industry setting, particularly as staff progress through their career to more senior managerial roles where they will supervise other staff.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"521d56e5dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5a1d56e5dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ae1d96e5dbd69c10eb6b147a3a9619a2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be provided a scenario and asked to formulate an appropriate strategy for the registration of a new therapeutic product and present that strategy and evidence for their decision to their managing director in a report. This assessment task will help students to develop their written communication skills, literature research skills and critical thinking skills. The written documents generated are valid documents that students would be expected to produce in this industry.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PHAR9114","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHAR9114 - Health Technology Assessment","description":"

Health Technology Assessment (HTA) focusses on the cost-benefit analysis of therapeutic interventions and the role of evidence-based medicine in determining the benefits of these interventions in health management. This course introduces students to the requirements for cost effectiveness for therapeutics and the role of evidence-based medicine in the decision-making process for these products. It covers pricing considerations for ensuring successful applications to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) for entry of medicines on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) and the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC) for Medicare rebates for medical services in Australia.  Students will also discuss the different economic methodologies used to determine the cost-benefit analysis of a medicine and when these different methodologies should be used. Students will learn about international HTA systems and engage in debate around the ethics and value determination of therapeutic products to society.


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"21dd9629dbd69c10eb6b147a3a9619e6","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Discussion Forum","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Contributions to the section-specific discussion forums are required in this course. Students are expected to contribute at least one post to each Discussion Forum during the semester. Posts should be no more than 200 words excluding supportive references. Students should submit their top three plus a 200-word paragraph outlining why they have chosen those particular three posts and why they consider them to be their best contributions to the discussions. Individual feedback will be provided via GradeMark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e5dd1a29dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e9dd1a29dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"eddd1a29dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eddd1a29dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0add1a29dbd69c10eb6b147a3a96196f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will be required to complete this task individually. Each student will be given a choice of product that was rejected recently by the PBAC or MSAC, asked to choose one and review the public summary documentation and extended literature about the product and indication. Students willprepare an executive summary for their re-submission for reimbursement, as per the PBAC or MSAC guidelines. Students will receive written feedback via Gradebook.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e9dd1a29dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"eddd1a29dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eddd1a29dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"31dd1a29dbd69c10eb6b147a3a96196b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Groupwork wiki project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will be placed into groups and each group will be assigned a therapeutic product class and asked to review the reimbursement environment in two different jurisdictions of their choosing for that product class. They will need to provide a comparison of the similarities and differences between the two systems and make recommendations for any appropriate improvements to both systems. They will need to justify their evaluation of these systems and their recommendations in a wiki. Students will receive group and individual feedback on their wiki. The assessment task will be presented as a Wiki. Students are required to peer review the contribution of their group members as well as peer review the final projects of other groups in the class using appropriate marking rubrics. Students will be provided with written feedback on their wiki and their individual contributions from their peer reviews. Ten percent of the marks will be individual, based on peer reviews by students and staff.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e5dd1a29dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e9dd1a29dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"eddd1a29dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eddd1a29dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3ddd1a29dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961958","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

This assessment task is designed to demonstrate an ability of students to integrate their course learning with their work environment, knowledge of the pharmaceutical industry and self-development.  Self-reflection is a powerful learning tool and can be applied throughout the student’s future career to discern their performance and where they should focus efforts to make improvements. Developing this skill and keeping a record of achievements and areas for improvement will prepare students for job interviews, performance reviews and promotions.


Students will be encouraged to reflect on the connections between their past, present and desired future skills, their current and future desired knowledge, their industry context, and the competencies and strategies required to achieve their career success. Employment in the pharmaceutical industry is very competitive and students will need to show prospective employers how they can meet their requirements and what competencies they will bring to their role.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHAR9115 - Advanced Health Technology Assessment","description":"

Health Technology Assessment (HTA) is a multidisciplinary science, involving a wide range of methodologies, which informs about the benefits and comparative value of interventions and provides a means by which health technologies can be assessed and prioritised against existing health care interventions This course introduces students to the wider requirements for assessing the cost-effectiveness of medical devices and diagnostics, and the role of evidence-based medicine in the decision-making process for these products. It covers pricing considerations for medical devices and diagnostics in the international arena and future applications and trends in the development of equitable access schemes for therapeutic products.  Students will study new modelling strategies required which can be used to gain reimbursement for therapeutic products.

Students will be provided a scenario and asked to formulate an appropriate strategy for the reimbursement of a new therapeutic product and present that strategy and evidence for their decision to their managing director in a report. This assessment task will help students to develop their written communication skills, literature research skills and critical thinking skills. The written documents generated are valid documents that students would be expected to produce in this industry.

Developing this skill and keeping a record of achievements and areas for improvement will prepare students for job interviews, performance reviews and promotions.

\n


Students will be encouraged to reflect on the connections between their past, present and desired future skills, their current and future desired knowledge, their industry context, and the competencies and strategies required to achieve their career success. Employment in the pharmaceutical and medical technology industry is very competitive and students will need to show prospective employers how they can meet their requirements and what competencies they will bring to their role.

Students will be placed in groups, assigned a therapeutic product class and asked to review the reimbursement environment in Australia versus another jurisdiction for that product class.  They will need to provide a comparison of the similarities and differences between the two systems and make recommendations for any appropriate improvements to both systems.  They will need to justify their evaluation of these systems and their recommendations.The assessment task will be presented as a wiki. Students will be expected to review the contribution of their group members as well as peer review the final projects of other groups in the class. This assessment task will develop students' skills in working cooperatively with colleagues located at a distance, similar to project teams they will be involved in when working in the therapeutics industry.  It will also help in the development of critical thinking skills by assessing their colleagues’ work and contributions to the team.  An ability to critically assess the work of others is vital in the industry setting, particularly as staff progress through their career to more senior managerial roles where they will supervise other staff.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PHAR9116","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHAR9116 - Clinical Trial Management","description":"

Clinical trials are an essential step in the development of a new therapeutic product. This course is designed to provide students with the skills to implement and manage clinical trials, including obtaining ethics approval. Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium (CDISC), electronic data capture and CONSORT will be discussed along with the creation, use, validation and security of electronic databases. Finally, the students will discuss the future of clinical trials in the development of new therapeutics and the global requirements for the conduct of clinical trials.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"61df12e9dbd69c10eb6b147a3a96199f","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Groupwork project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be assigned to groups and asked to develop their clinical management plan for a Phase III global trial in a particular therapeutic area. Students will be required to assess the performance of their group members using a rubric. Thirty marks will be for the final group presentation and 10 for individual performance based on peer review. Feedback will be provided to each student.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"139fdaa9dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961921","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"279fdaa9dbd69c10eb6b147a3a96199c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

This assessment task is designed to demonstrate an ability of students to integrate their course learning with their work environment, knowledge of the pharmaceutical industry and self-development.  Self-reflection is a powerful learning tool and can be applied throughout the student’s future career to discern their performance and where they should focus efforts to make improvements. Developing this skill and keeping a record of achievements and areas for improvement will prepare students for job interviews, performance reviews and promotions.

 

Students will be encouraged to reflect on the connections between their past, present and desired future skills, their current and future desired knowledge, their industry context, and the competencies and strategies required to achieve their career success. Employment in the pharmaceutical industry is very competitive and students will need to show prospective employers how they can meet their requirements and what competencies they will bring to their role.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1b9fdaa9dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9b9fdaa9dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961923","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to prepare a written essay on the challenges and issues of managing global, multi-centre, multi-country clinical trials. Individual feedback will be provided via Gradebook.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"139fdaa9dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1b9fdaa9dbd69c10eb6b147a3a961921","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ab9fdaa9dbd69c10eb6b147a3a96199e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Discussion Forums","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Contributions to the section-specific discussion forums are required in this course. Students are expected to contribute at least one post to each Discussion Forum during the semester. Posts should be no more than 200 words excluding supportive references. Students should submit their top three plus a 200-word paragraph outlining why they have chosen those particular three posts and why they consider them to be their best contributions to the discussions. Individual feedback will be provided via GradeMark.

The course is designed to provide students with the skills to understand the molecular basis of cancer development and progression.  It covers the development of various therapeutic treatment options and guides students to an assessment of the optimal treatment options available for various cancers.  Students will explore the way cancer medicines are assessed for safety and efficacy and how patients are monitored for response to therapy.  Recent advances in pharmacology, pharmacogenetics, molecular biology and data analysis have converged to revolutionise the treatment of cancer, extending patient lifespans and turning some cancers into chronic conditions.  Targeted therapies are rapidly improving patient outcomes while reducing un-necessary exposure in patients unlikely to respond to a particular therapy.  The future now is how to combine therapies and rationally choose the best treatment options for an individual patient at different stages of their disease.  Finally we look into the ethics and economics of cancer therapy and how and who should bear the burden of cost for these new advances in clinical medicine.

Contributions to the section-specific discussion forums are required in this course. Students are expected to contribute at least one post to each Discussion Forum during the semester. Posts should be no more than 200 words excluding supportive references. Students should submit their top three plus a 200-word paragraph outlining why they have chosen those particular three posts and why they consider them to be their best contributions to the discussions. Individual feedback will be provided via GradeMark.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"301202b9db16dc10eb6b147a3a96191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3c1202b9db16dc10eb6b147a3a96191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"701242b9db16dc10eb6b147a3a96190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"701242b9db16dc10eb6b147a3a96190e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"701242b9db16dc10eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"781242b9db16dc10eb6b147a3a96190c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"781242b9db16dc10eb6b147a3a96190d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"011242b9db16dc10eb6b147a3a961927","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

There will be two essay options for this course - one for students undertaking a degree in Pharmaceutical Medicine and one for students taking the course as a non-award course.

1a.      Essay Information for Pharmaceutical Medicine Students:

The assignment is focused on the medicines development component of the course.  The overall purpose of the assignment is to encourage the student to research a particular disease in detail, evaluate the therapeutic options available, identify potential new areas of medicines development and then discuss the development plan and regulatory and reimbursement strategies for a new agent in this disease state.  Hence the assignment will bring together the therapeutic knowledge gained in these courses, with the overall understanding of medicines development gained in prior courses.

 

For the assignment for this course, students are required to select one of the cancer types identified in the table below and relevant to this course and discuss the development of a potential new therapy using a new target for which no current therapeutic agent has been marketed.

If a student wishes to select a different cancer type, please discuss with the Course Convenor.

The assignment should cover the following areas:

vBackground: Brief discussion of the cancer type and the pathophysiological mechanisms involved.  Outline of available therapies and the targets/mechanisms addressed by these therapies, including the advantages and deficiencies of these therapies.

vRationale: Review of the potential targets and mechanisms involved (or believed to be involved) in the cancer and a more in depth discussion of the target or mechanism identified as being a good potential drug target.  The target chosen may be a new target or may be an existing target but where the available therapies have significant limitations.

vLandscape: Brief outline of what medicines development is occurring currently in this cancer type (your competitor intelligence).

vOpportunity: Discussion of the (potential) clinical advantages of a therapeutic agent addressing this target or mechanism (including potential deficiencies) and why it would be a good area of medicines development to pursue.  Outline the ideal characteristics of this agent and how you would show “proof of concept” before beginning clinical development.

vDevelopment: Description of a clinical development plan (Phase I-III) for this agent.  Consideration of the current “standard of care” is important in discussing a clinical trial program.  It is not expected that students provide draft protocols but rather an outline of the types of studies that would need to be performed at each Phase, with an emphasis on Phase III. 

v   Strategy:  Regulatory and reimbursement strategies.  The global regulatory and reimbursement strategies for the successful development and marketing of this new therapeutic should be discussed including any post-marketing studies, registries or other commitments that may ensure a successful launch for this therapeutic.

 

In doing this assignment, it is expected that students will review current literature on medicines development and see what potential targets of interest and new therapeutic agents are being developed in the chosen cancer type.  It is not expected that students address any commercial considerations in their assignment (e.g. is the drug likely to be a commercial success?).  Rather, the focus is on understanding the cancer type, identifying the medical need and the requirements, including regulatory and reimbursement strategies, to develop a medicine to meet this need.

It is expected that the assignment should be approximately 5000 words.

1b.      Essay Information for Non-award Course-enrolled Students:

Non-award course-enrolled students will not have had the advantage of doing the other courses in the Pharmaceutical Medicine program to give them sufficient expertise to cover the assignment topic described above.  Therefore your assignment topic will be as follows:

Choose a cancer type from the table below and compare and contrast two different classes of medicine used to treat this type of cancer in the last decade.  Your essay should cover all of the course topics for these two classes of medicine, that is, mode of action, toxicities, dosage and administration, monitoring of treatment success.  You should also address the pitfalls in the currently available therapies and the challenges for future therapy development including the possibility of combining therapies to treat this cancer type.

 Cancer Types for Essays:

Colon cancer

Brain and spinal cord cancers

Endometrial/ovarian cancers

Melanoma

Paediatric cancers

Head and neck cancers

Testicular cancers

Pancreatic cancers

Leukaemia

Liver cancer

Lung cancers

Bone cancers

Lymphoma

Other haematological cancers

Kidney cancers

Breast cancer

 Note:  Topic choice selection will be available from the first week of semester.  You should choose your topic early, since once a student has selected a topic, it will no longer be available for other students to choose.

 

 

 

 

 

Written and verbal feedback based on the course learning outcomes will be provided to the student within 2 weeks of submission of their draft assignment outline.

The reflection should consider the feedback the student has received and how they have attempted to incorporate that feedback into their essay. It should also indicate how the student thinks that the tasks associated with this course have helped them personally in their understanding of the medicines development process and the pharmaceutical industry. The reflective piece should be no more than 500 words.

The oral presentation will be delivered via a Blackboard Collaborate session to the class in week 10 of the semester. The student is expected to prepare an oral presentation based on Powerpoint to deliver to the class. Their presentation should be no longer than 15 minutes. They should cover the topic that they addressed in their written research project. If all presentations cannot be finished in one BB Collaborate session, then there will be a second session the following evening. Students should take into consideration the questions, comments and feedback they receive from their oral presentation in finalising their written essay.

Students are expected to peer review each other’s presentations.  10% of your assessment mark for this task will be based on your ability to critically assess your fellow student’s presentations.


Feedback will be written and verbal comments on their work based on the course learning outcomes and whether these were achieved.

This course will introduce students to various therapeutic areas and enable them to develop an understanding of the molecular basis of disease, how this knowledge is used to develop new therapies and how to apply their learnings from previous courses to develop clinical, regulatory and reimbursement strategies to ensure a new molecule has an optimal chance of making it onto the market. The core therapeutics areas covered will include cardiovascular, endocrinology, neurology and infectious diseases.  Other areas will be covered briefly and students may choose to study a specific therapeutic area of their choosing for their main assignment to allow for individual interests.  

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b4c282f9db16dc10eb6b147a3a961967","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

This assessment task is designed to demonstrate an ability of students to integrate their course learning with their work environment, knowledge of the pharmaceutical industry and self-development.  Self-reflection is a powerful learning tool and can be applied throughout the student’s future career to discern their performance and where they should focus efforts to make improvements. Developing this skill and keeping a record of achievements and areas for improvement will prepare students for job interviews, performance reviews and promotions.

\n


Students will be encouraged to reflect on the connections between their past, present and desired future skills, their current and future desired knowledge, their industry context, and the competencies and strategies required to achieve their career success. Employment in the pharmaceutical industry is very competitive and students will need to show prospective employers how they can meet their requirements and what competencies they will bring to their role.

Contributions to the section-specific discussion forums are required in this course. Students are expected to contribute at least one post to each Discussion Forum during the semester. Posts should be no more than 200 words excluding supportive references. Students should submit their top three plus a 200-word paragraph outlining why they have chosen those particular three posts and why they consider them to be their best contributions to the discussions. Individual feedback will be provided via GradeMark.

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"11a2ceb9db16dc10eb6b147a3a9619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"19a2ceb9db16dc10eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"19a2ceb9db16dc10eb6b147a3a9619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1da28eb9db16dc10eb6b147a3a9619b2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"29a2ceb9db16dc10eb6b147a3a9619b1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be assigned to a group and each group of students will be assigned a disease state and asked to present their topic to the class in the Blackboard Collaborate webinars.  Each group will be allocated their topic 2 weeks before their presentation. The presentation will help build confidence in students’ presentation skills and reflects the skills expected from UNSW graduates.  Students will need to interact with their fellow students by asking questions and posting comments in the associated discussion forum. This will increase the development of their critical appraisal skills and ability to ask questions. They will be expected to assess the presentations of their fellow students, which will help them with their ability to review the work of their colleagues and staff - an essential skill for a manager – to be able to review the work of others and give positive feedback to enable them to develop to their full potential.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"19a2ceb9db16dc10eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"99a2ceb9db16dc10eb6b147a3a9619ae","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

The overall purpose of the assignment is to encourage the student to research a particular disease in detail, evaluate the therapeutic options available, identify potential new areas of medicines development and then discuss the clinical development plan, regulatory strategy and reimbursement strategy for a new agent in this disease state. Each student will investigate a different disease state. Students are given the opportunity to submit a draft proposal for feedback early in the semester. This assessment task will help students to develop their written communication skills, literature research skills and critical thinking skills. The written document could be used to form the basis of a publication by the student on their topic.

contentlets.description: This course will introduce students to various therapeutic areas and enable them to develop an understanding of the molecular basis of disease, how this knowledge is used to develop new therapies and how to apply their learnings from previous courses to develop clinical, regulatory and reimbursement strategies to ensure a new molecule has an optimal chance of making it onto the market. The core therapeutics areas covered will include cardiovascular, endocrinology, neurology and infectious diseases.  Other areas will be covered briefly and students may choose to study a specific therapeutic area of their choosing for their main assignment to allow for individual interests.
contentlets.title: Therapeutics

Clinical Trials pertains to the design, development, safe conduct and interpretation of trials for therapeutic products in humans.  This course is designed to provide students with the skills to interpret the clinical literature, understand Good Clinical Practice (GCP) and clinical development and give students the skills to design and analyse clinical trials from first time in man Phase I through to Phase II, III and IV trials and registries. The course examines the importance of  pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic and pharmacogenomic studies in humans. Adaptive clinical trial designs are also examined. Novel clinical trial endpoints such as surrogate endpoints and biomarkers will be discussed.  Trial designs for different types of therapeutic products will be examined, as will the ethics of clinical trials.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e1866fe8db739450eb6b147a3a9619a0","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

In this assignment, students will be assigned to a particular scenario and will be required to write a protocol synopsis for two clinical studies (one exploratory study and one confirmatory study) based on the trial scenario provided. Individual feedback will be provided via GradeMark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a586232cdb739450eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e9866fe8db739450eb6b147a3a9619a1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2586632cdb739450eb6b147a3a961903","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Group project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will be placed in groups, assigned a type of clinical trial design and asked to present their analysis of the design to the class. The assessment task will be presented as a wiki. Students will be expected to review the contribution of their group members as well as peer review the final projects of other groups in the class. This assessment task will develop students' skills in working cooperatively with colleagues located at a distance, similar to project teams they will be involved in when working in the therapeutics industry.  It will also help in the development of critical thinking skills by assessing their colleagues’ work and contributions to the team.  An ability to critically assess the work of others is vital in the industry setting, particularly as staff progress through their career to more senior managerial roles where they will supervise other staff. The group assessment is worth 30 marks, and the individual peer assessment is work 5 marks. Individual and group feedback will be provided.

Posts should be no more than 200 words excluding supportive references. Students should submit their top three plus a 200-word paragraph outlining why they have chosen those particular three posts and why they consider them to be their best contributions to the discussions. Individual feedback will be provided via GradeMark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a586232cdb739450eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ad86232cdb739450eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e9866fe8db739450eb6b147a3a9619a1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ed866fe8db739450eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6d86632cdb739450eb6b147a3a961906","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

This assessment task is designed to demonstrate an ability of students to integrate their course learning with their work environment, knowledge of the pharmaceutical industry and self-development.  Self-reflection is a powerful learning tool and can be applied throughout the student’s future career to discern their performance and where they should focus efforts to make improvements. Developing this skill and keeping a record of achievements and areas for improvement will prepare students for job interviews, performance reviews and promotions.

\n


Students will be encouraged to reflect on the connections between their past, present and desired future skills, their current and future desired knowledge, their industry context, and the competencies and strategies required to achieve their career success. Employment in the pharmaceutical industry is very competitive and students will need to show prospective employers how they can meet their requirements and what competencies they will bring to their role.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PHAR9121","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHAR9121 - Pharmacovigilance","description":"

Pharmacovigilance (PV) is the science and activities relating to the detection, assessment, understanding and prevention of adverse effects or any other drug-related problems.  This course will cover the identification and quantification of risk associated with medicines,  recognition and interpretation of adverse drug reactions (ADRs) and their underlying toxicopathology and pharmacology and the regulatory requirements for pre-clinical testing including toxicity studies. Students will learns to write and interpret a number of documents associated with pharmacovigilance including Risk Management Plans (RMPs), Periodic Safety Update Reports (PSURs), Periodic Benefit-Risk Evaluation Report (PBRER), Development Safety Update Reports (DSURs). The international and Australian guidelines for adverse event reporting, international (ICH) guidelines, European and US PV systems, the role of the qualified person and compliance will be addressed in the course.

Students will be provided a presentation topic and given 2 weeks to prepare a group presentation to be given during the webinars. Each group member will provide peer review of their group members and their group presentations will be peer reviewed during the webinars. Group and individual feedback will be provided the students.

Contributions to the section-specific discussion forums are required in this course. Students are expected to contribute at least one post to each Discussion Forum during the semester. Posts should be no more than 200 words excluding supportive references. Students should submit their top three plus a 200-word paragraph outlining why they have chosen those particular three posts and why they consider them to be their best contributions to the discussions. Individual feedback will be provided via GradeMark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2575c2bddb16dc10eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2975c2bddb16dc10eb6b147a3a9619c2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2d75c2bddb16dc10eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2d75c2bddb16dc10eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e175c2bddb16dc10eb6b147a3a9619c6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be given a choice of products and expected to develop a pharmacovigilance plan for their chosen product. Details will be provided in class and students will be provided with feedback via GradeMark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2575c2bddb16dc10eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f17506bddb16dc10eb6b147a3a96190c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

This assessment task is designed to demonstrate an ability of students to integrate their course learning with their work environment, knowledge of the pharmaceutical industry and self-development.  Self-reflection is a powerful learning tool and can be applied throughout the student’s future career to discern their performance and where they should focus efforts to make improvements. Developing this skill and keeping a record of achievements and areas for improvement will prepare students for job interviews, performance reviews and promotions.


Students will be encouraged to reflect on the connections between their past, present and desired future skills, their current and future desired knowledge, their industry context, and the competencies and strategies required to achieve their career success. Employment in the pharmaceutical industry is very competitive and students will need to show prospective employers how they can meet their requirements and what competencies they will bring to their role.

Medical Affairs is an emerging specialisation within the pharmaceutical industry which is responsible for managing key opinion-leader relationships, publishing data from corporate-sponsored trials, presenting educational information about a product or therapeutic landscape, answering questions from healthcare providers regarding product safety or efficacy that is not addressed in a product’s label and supporting research initiatives outside labeled indications for marketed products. This course will cover the international and local ethical, legal and marketing codes of compliance, quality use of medicines as well as the writing and interpretation of key scientific documents such as product information, consumer medicine information and clinical trial results. Off-label use of medicines and access to unlicensed products will be covered.  Product withdrawals will also be discussed. Medical Governance principles and strategic alignment with business goals, development of Medical Affairs plans, understanding Advisory Boards’ objectives, development of local medical research initiatives and how to develop a local publication strategy will be covered in the course.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"218606fddb16dc10eb6b147a3a96198a","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online QUM plus Individual Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

A. Online QUM

The aim of this assessment task is to familiarise students with the concept of Quality Use of Medicines and where it fits in the Australian National Medicines Policy.  This assessment is based on a fully online tutorial module developed by the National Prescribing Service. NPS provides a certificate of completion, which will be submitted as evidence of completion of this assessment task. This assessment task is worth 5 marks.

B. Medical Information Assignment

Students will be given a piece of promotional material for this assessment task with the minimum Product Information section removed and will be asked to review the promotional material for compliance with the Medicines Australia Code of Conduct and write a Code-compliant minimum PI for the product. Students will be required to justify their review and minimum PI. This assessment task is worth 30 marks. Students will be provided feedback in GradeMark.
